caseTitle: ATTORNEY GENERAL & ANOR. v APAADE LODGE LIMITED
summary: The Supreme Court of Ghana dismissed a repeat application by Apaade Lodge Limited for a stay of execution of a High Court default judgment dated 4 April 2006. The applicant had failed to appeal against the judgment but sought relief under the Court's inherent jurisdiction under Article 129(4) of the 1992 Constitution, arguing that justice required a stay pending appeal against a later Court of Appeal decision. The Court held that it could only exercise such powers when a matter is already within its jurisdiction, and since no appeal had been filed against the High Court judgment, it lacked jurisdiction to grant a stay. It reaffirmed that procedural rules under the Supreme Court Rules (C.I. 16), particularly Rule 20, require an appeal to be lodged before a stay application can be entertained. The Court also clarified that while default judgments are typically challenged by application to set aside, an appeal is still a legitimate remedy. The application was dismissed for non-compliance with procedural requirements.
verdict: Application for stay of execution dismissed.
citations: Edusei (No.1) v. Attorney General and Anr. [1996-97] SCGLR 1
Tait v. Ghana Airways Corporation [1970] 2 G & G 527
Accra Recreational Complex Ltd. vs. Lands Commission Supreme Court, 20th June 2007 (unreported)
NB. Landmark Ltd. v. Lakiani [2001-2002] SCGLR 318
rationaleHighlights: The Supreme Court lacks jurisdiction to stay a judgment not appealed against, even under Article 129(4).
Article 129(4) does not confer original jurisdiction ab initio but applies only when a matter is already within the Court's jurisdiction.
A party must first appeal against a judgment before seeking a stay of execution under Rule 20 of the Supreme Court Rules.
Default judgments may be appealed, contrary to counsel's submission that setting aside is the only remedy.
The Court rejected the argument that inherent jurisdiction allows circumvention of procedural rules to prevent failure of justice.
confidenceNotes: The ruling is clear and well-reasoned, with consistent reference to constitutional provisions, statutory rules, and binding precedents. The procedural posture is unambiguous, and the court's conclusions are firmly grounded in established law.
